comments.commentBody: Dear Mr. Davidson, with all due respect sir, I'm a land and mineral owner near Williston, ND and you don't have any idea what your talking about.

The government has forced drilling onto private farms and land in populated areas  because of the moratorium against federal land drilling and exploration. Development will still occur in the towns as it did in Rock Springs WYO.when there was drilling on federal land. There are farmers and such who refuse the leases and the money in N Dakota although they are few ,they are independent sorts.
Only if you itnore the horrible suffering of Serbs who were mass expelled after NATO occupation.

The coin laundry, which I introduced to Japan starting in 1972, was as much a cultural intrusion as chewing gum or Coca-Cola.

I'd been lecturing and studying, had to do my laundry, found no coin laundries, and, being a good Westerner, researched the question before diving into the industry.

"You Americans," I was told time and time again, "are all very rational, but we Japanese understand women's souls. Japanese women love to do laundry," I was told time and time again. With squads of students surveying, I found this view very widespread: everybody bought it except one demographic: women over the age of 28, those who had been married for a while. For them, as for me, it was horsefeathers.

I opened my first store in Kokubunji, a suburb of west Tokyo, and people lined up down the block. Over the next twelve years I built 400 more, all over the country.

Japanese firms of course followed, and now there are coin laundries everywhere. There's also been a strictly cultural change, in education. Doing laundry -- by hand, in cold water -- is no longer where it used to be on the school curriculum: Grade Three. For girls.

-dlj.
Unimportant to you that is Most jobs are unimportant to people not involved in them. Don't begrudge what other people earn, Envy is an ugly thing.

Although I agree that Democrats should be more vocal in their support of the president and his many successful policies and programs, I offer a word of defense for those Democratic candidates in the fall elections accused of "running away" from him.  Nearly all of them were running in fairly red states, and linking themselves more to the president would not have helped them.  They would only have lost by more.

.Why the economy did not create more jobs faster, here is one example, brought to you by their presidential candidate.
http://www.thenation.com/article/170644/mitt-romneys-bailout-bonanza#

And another:
http://mirtamimansary.com/romneys-pranks/

As you can see from these two examples, the GOP and The Murdoch owned Fox have managed a disingenuous propaganda campaign as good as any any of us have seen in our lifetimes.

Mr. Obama has had to operate almost alone, while even the Dems run away, afraid to confront the GOP on the ACA, and making false claims about him and Wall Street. As has been said many time, it is not my enemies I worry about.

I have never seen such cowardly behavior by the president party before, anyone who has not supported Mr. Obama during all this strife should be ashamed for such opprobrious behavior.

Enemies on the left, enemies on the right, stuck in purgatory with you.
Or the poor person that loses a loved one the day before a critical interview that can't be rescheduled.

Obama's employees recently lied to and spied on Congress and he allows it.

Not Bush. So Stu, is your ignoring that, which it is almost certain you know, for just one example, a half truth, or a simple unitary deceit? The list can go on.

And why is it that when republicans win elections it doesn't count except to explain dumbies were deceived? Not even the false consciousness shtick, but smart lefties are rare in America. Kinda like the servile confederate republican belief no democrat can ever be president. Thoughtless.

One solution, ignore the issues. Throw around half truth talk per handler protocol. Same as with Bush. So the oligarchs can continue to rule the National Security State unimpeded.

To avoid unseemly bragging, it helps to have a chorus on side. It is not entirely Obama's fault that he did not.

Still, it puts an unfortunate highlight on the value of being a cheerleader or actor, playing to an audience rather than doing the hard job.

The best Presidents had people to do that, or at least help him do it. See JFK backed by Sorenson, etc. Who is Obama's Sorenson?

The President has an audience of over 300 million. He must deal with it.

As times and technology and personalities change, how to do that changes. FDR had Fireside Chats, but they can't work the same today when people don't gather around the radio, and the President does not have the voice and manner of FDR on the radio.

Obama does not seem to have found a method that works for him, nor to have the help he needs from staff or from Party on side.

<In my best John Boehner voice> Are you KIDDING ME??

http://youtu.be/QYGgVSNoUkw

How many people actually live within a budget in terms of balancing it every year? Most people have debt thanks to credit cards, cars, or their homes.

Do we really want individuals printing money? People can borrow money from banks or get credit cards which is very similar to printing money. Credit is a way of creating new money.

The US government can borrow money at effectively a zero interest rate because it's considered such a good credit risk. That's the markets talking, not the government. I would also add that people are frequently given deals to borrow money for cars and the like at zero interest rates.

The government holds approximately $330 billion in gold, a great deal of money, but in the context of the US economy and the federal budget, a relatively small amount.

Obviously, you have one standard for the government and one standard for everyone else.

I would end by saying the government is an extension of all of us, it's not the government was some entity that conquered us and is an occupying force.

I don't believe the author is arguing against travel are youthful spirit. He is pointing out, much like Charles Murrey did in Coming Apart, that there is a cultural shift going on. More and more young people are having babies without marriage. They aren't serious about school or career. Every waking minute has to be filled with entertainment and fun.

@Clyde Wynant

You see, you are one of those stuck in the who will pay for it mentality.
There are a myriad ways to make enough to get by without having to go to the office every day. I can take my electrical skills, go to villages and help the locals improve things, have a place to sleep and eat, and even earn a few coins.

When I was younger, the trick was to get on a ship and work your way across the ocean. I have known many who managed to travel the world, then came back and used their experience to do well.

Get stuck in that who will pay for it mentality, and end up in a cubicle.

@Nancy

Actually I am the one who pays most of the bills. As far as we could determine, that couple saved for the trip themselves.

Put it off as long as you can. You are only young once. Put on a backpack and see the world. Have a love affair in Paris, and maybe several other places. Climb the Alps, surf in Malibu, see Kathmandu. The worldly experiences will give you a broader perspective, you will enjoy life all along the way.

We mat a couple in Shanghai that were taking their three young kids on a around the world trip. Traveling by train, staying in hostels, what a great experience for them. We were Beatniks, it gave us a more open view of the world, drinking wine, listening to poetry. You get old too soon as it is. You wake up some day, your kids have kids, you have arthritis, it hurts to ski all day, to hell with adulthood.

Notice how many people who did not charge into adulthood, who went to Paris, became famous writers, or leaders of society. As my wife keeps saying, "When are you going to grow up? Well, I am not, I am a kid at heart, growing up is for old fogies.

You do know in the Bakken, a well has about a 3 year life cycle (fall off of ~70% in the first year, continued in the second and third to the well is producing about 10 to 20% of that first year at the end of 3 - effectively a stripper well) and they have about drilled in all the best spots. Look for production from the Dakotas to gradually begin to fall in the next couple of years. At $65 a barrel is anyone there actually making money or is the Bakken a big ponzi play. Collect several $Million from investors, sink a hole use the initial money from that hole to pay for making a new hole, wash, rinse, repeat.

How well the engineers did (or were allowed by their bosses to do) will come out when we see the extent of the environmental damage and pollution.  Of course, if some rural districts depopulate because environmental problems make them less livable, that is the sort of social planning thing we try to avoid thinking about.
What with the concentration of the national income and wealth at the very top, we have an ample supply of investors.

Next year the US will overtake Saudi Arabia as the world largest oil producer .

The government did well, but American engineers did even better.
No, they won't.  And my guess is they have only begun to fight.  The next presidential election will make all previous ones look tame.

I think the record will show that the Right is particularly savage and unrelenting when it comes to attacking other groups bargaiining power, where that group's main raison d'etre is highly correlated to an economic interest.

The Right exploited homophobes, but didn't really mind giving in on the issue of gay marriage and acceptence of homosexuals. That did really effect people's bargaining power, the Right's pocket book and disarmed a strong anti-right group.

But they were unrelenting in attacking ACORN's whose simple mission was to help the pooresst of the poor to realize the limited amount of bargaining power our system gives them. Truly the Right is dominated by sociopaths without a conscience or empathy for the poor.

Collective bargaining is evil. but collective ownership, the limited liability joint stock corporation, is perfectly okay.

A brilliant hypothesis that rings true. Strategy of oligachs for accumulating money and power (to accumulate more money): keep the masses desperate so that they will settle for poverty-level wages. Obamacare makes the masses less desperate.
I do not paint all wealthy people with the same rush. Consider wealthy people like Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt who used their privileged background as a springboard to help other Americans advance out of poverty and despair.
What makes the difference, I wonder, between those who pursue wealth for its own sake and are quite willing to denigrate others in the process, and those who understand that wealth and privilege create a calling to serve others? How did we let the concept of patriotism deteriorate into jingoism, rather than understanding patriotism as a calling to do our fair share in building this great country and leaving it a better place to live for coming generations?

Prof. Krugman predicted that the economy would gradually recover as household debt decreased. It appears that that has been happening since 2010. Each monthy we saw between 100k and 200k job growth and each year 2-3% GNP growth. But then suddenly this year there was a positive inflection. Now we're averaging job growth greater than 200k/mo and GNP growth greater than 3% a year.

Something happened in January 2014 to cause that inflection point. It could be a combination of many things, but the one outstanding event in January 2014 was the full implementation of Obamacare. At the very least it has not retarded growth and in the extent may be empowering it.

The Great Recession was dominated by demand deficiency. Demand comes from wages, when it isn't coming from increased household debt.

The GOP's prime directive is the pursuit of ever greater concentrations of wealth and power on behalf of the 1/10%ers. Towards this, they pursue the undermining of all other groups bargaining power: Unions for workers, affordable education for the aspiring middle class, even ACORN for the very poorest. They've been very successful as the median wage hasn't gone up since 1972 while GNP has.

Weak bargaining power suppresses wages, which suppresses demand, which suppresses growth in GNP.

This suggests the real reason for opposition to Obamacare. People don't need jobs anymore to get health insurance. This shifts bargaining power away from the 1/10th%ers.

Prediction: they will NEVER accept it.

Desperate people also sometimes make bad choices based on hope, rather than realizing one setback--reduced work hours, for example--could ruin their plans. Having been there myself thanks to unemployment in the Great Recession, I know how tempting it can be to take whatever terms are available and pray that nothing goes wrong. In my case, I made it out of the bad times, but was hit by serious health problems once I had a real job--and insurance. If the cancer had struck when I was unemployed, I would have lost everything.

"Voluntarily tethered to a team he couldn’t have imagined would have the league’s most losses at this point in the season, Anthony has become the leading candidate to be considered the most aggrieved $100 million player."

Uhhhh.

First, if he couldn't imagine it, well, it is hard to see how he is able to feed himself if his faculties are so deficient.

Second, "most aggrieved". Shilling has no shame. Perhaps Harvey is making fun of humself with a sly wink about an aggrieved 100 million dollar man, but his written record provides no reason to believe he has a sense of humor.

Funny how the one name league has a parallel in a reporter who reports not on the Knicks or basketball but on Anthony. Second Wind, written before Anthiny was born, has a better discussion of the one man issue in the NBA than this tired effort. Too bad Anthony didn't read the book back in college.

In discussing whether ACA is working, the two issues I raised can not be separated.
It is a fact coverage has increased and it is a fact taxes on the rich have increased and they don't want to pay these taxes.
If you want to argue that there are much better programs for health care than ACA, then I agree.
I would have preferred extending Medicare for all or at least providing a government option.
But that is a different discussion.
And I agree it is an important discussion.
But the main opposition to ACA is not from those who want either of these two. It is from those whose taxes have been increased.
But they can not say that directly.
So instead they argue that ACA is not working because to them the increased taxes are not worth extending coverage to OTHERS.
But the conservatives who want to repeal ACA have NO program to provide increased coverage.
To accept their arguments means loss of protections like being denied coverage for pre-existing conditions and other such features in ACA.
Have all the philosophical discussions you want.
And they are important.
But to preserve ACA [as imperfect as it is] means pointing out the cruel greedy hypocrisy of those who want repeal..
That is why I disagree with you and believe the two issues I raised above can not be separated in discussing whether ACA "is working".

I'm inclined to see Obama in a similar light to Truman. While doing a consulting gig in Kansas City I decided to read Harry Truman's biography. I was talking him up when my father told me that when he left the White House he wasn't very well liked.

I now realize that by 1953 when he left the White House the right had been out of the White House for 20 years. Regardless of the successes or failures they attacked Truman because if they didn't they'd never be able to succeed him. This was the time of communist witch hunts: false theater not politics of substance.

Once gone, Truman was no longer a threat to the Right and so their media had no reason to attack him. They moved on to present and future threats. Presidents would move on to react to such false theater:"the soft on communism" meme laid the ground work to our prolonged period in Vietnam.

Meanwhile with politics moving on only historians and biographers remained to analyse Truman and all they saw was the long list of smart policy achievements. Perhaps his greatest failure being universal health insurance.

When Clinton left office the right wing media actually started talking up Hillary as SoS. Now she's a potential threat so they are talking her down again.

No doubt when Obama is gone the evidence is going suggest he was one of our greater presidents. Mostly because he faced great challenges: a collapsing economy that could have ended everything. He's also our 1st African-American president, a stunning achievement.
The national average family premium hit $16, 000 two years ago.
After seeing the failure of the previous majority in the House, anything will be better.
It is the other way around: Congress didn't do their job which is why Obama has had to use his authority and move forward without them.
Given the standard of the Texas educational system, this is not good news.
Trust me folks--this ain't a good thing.
Fantastic. Now maybe they can run this bankrupt national government like Texas and get us back on track.
lucky united states of America....
